questions.text: On exam of airway posterior Pharyngeal wall with faucial pillars with uvula without tip is seen. His MPG is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 2 The Mallampati classification (MPG) is used to assess the visibility of the structures in the oral cavity and pharynx to predict the ease of intubation. The classification is based on the visibility of the posterior pharyngeal wall, faucial pillars, and uvula when the patient is sitting with their mouth open and tongue out. Here’s how the Mallampati classification works: Class 1: The uvula, faucial pillars, and soft palate are fully visible. Class 2: The uvula and faucial pillars are visible, but the tip of the uvula may not be visible. Class 3: Only the soft palate and the base of the uvula are visible. Class 4: Only the hard palate is visible, and no part of the uvula is visible. In the description provided, the posterior pharyngeal wall with faucial pillars and uvula without tip is seen, which corresponds to Class 2 in the Mallampati classification. This is because the uvula is visible, but not the tip, indicating that it's a Class 2 airway. Incorrect Answers: A. 0: There is no Mallampati classification called "0". The correct classifications are from Class 1 to Class 4. B. 1: Class 1 would mean that all structures including the uvula, faucial pillars, and soft palate are visible, which is not the case here. D. 3: In Class 3, only the soft palate and the base of the uvula are visible, which is more restrictive than what is described here, where the uvula is still partially visible.

questions.text: Lacks system is modification of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mapleson A The Lack's system is a modification of the Mapleson A circuit. The Mapleson circuits are types of breathing circuits used in anesthesia for delivering oxygen and inhalation agents to patients. Mapleson A (also known as the "Magill circuit") is a type of open anesthesia circuit where the fresh gas flow enters the circuit and a reservoir bag is connected. The patient's exhaled gas is vented out to the atmosphere through an adjustable valve. The Lack's system was developed as an improvement to the Mapleson A system. The primary difference is the addition of an endotracheal tube for more efficient airway management, especially for controlled ventilation in patients who need continuous positive pressure ventilation. Incorrect Answers: B. Mapleson B: The Mapleson B circuit is similar to Mapleson A, but it has the fresh gas flow entering closer to the patient's airway and the reservoir bag further down the circuit. It is a simpler design, and the Lack's system is not based on it. C. Mapleson C: The Mapleson C circuit is another modification of the Mapleson circuits, with the fresh gas entering at the distal end of the circuit. It is also different from the Lack's system, which is a modification of Mapleson A. D. Mapleson D: The Mapleson D circuit is also used in anesthesia and has a similar design to Mapleson A but includes some changes in where the fresh gas is introduced and how the exhaust is directed. Again, the Lack's system is not based on this modification.

questions.text: The cuff suited for long term ventilation is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) High volume, low pressure For long-term ventilation, the high volume, low pressure cuff is most suitable. This type of cuff ensures a large surface area contact with the tracheal wall and maintains a low pressure against the tracheal mucosa. This helps in preventing ischemic injury to the tracheal tissues, reducing the risk of pressure necrosis and allowing for more prolonged use, especially in patients requiring long-term endotracheal intubation. Incorrect Answers: B. Low volume, high pressure: A low volume, high pressure cuff is not suitable for long-term ventilation because it can create a high pressure on a smaller area of the tracheal wall. This increases the risk of mucosal damage, tracheal stenosis, and pressure ulcers. It is more commonly used for short-term intubation. C. Low volume, low pressure: While this cuff may reduce pressure, it is not ideal for long-term use because it may not form a secure seal around the airway, leading to potential air leaks and inadequate ventilation. A high-volume cuff is better at ensuring a more effective seal while still maintaining lower pressure on the trachea. D. High volume, high pressure: A high volume, high pressure cuff is generally used for short-term ventilation but is not suitable for prolonged use. The high pressure exerted on the tracheal wall can lead to tracheal damage, necrosis, and other complications over time. It does not provide the optimal balance of pressure distribution for long-term care.

Option b: RAE( Ring Aldaire Elvin ) are preformed tubes and are tube of choice for head and neck surgery to improve visualization during the surgery. questions.text: Combined oral contraceptives should be stopped at least…… week before surgery
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 4 Combined oral contraceptives (COCs) should generally be stopped at least 4 weeks before surgery, particularly if the surgery involves major procedures or if there is an increased risk of thrombosis (blood clots). COCs increase the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE), and stopping them before surgery allows the risk to decrease as the body’s natural hormonal balance is restored. Stopping COCs 4 weeks prior to surgery is particularly important in patients undergoing major surgery, immobilization, or those with additional risk factors for clot formation. Incorrect Answers: A. 1 week: Stopping COCs only 1 week before surgery may still leave the patient at elevated risk for clotting due to the relatively short period for the body to regain a normal coagulation profile. B. 2 weeks: Stopping 2 weeks before surgery may still not allow enough time for the increased clotting risk to dissipate, especially for patients undergoing high-risk procedures. D. 3 weeks: While 3 weeks can be a safer time frame than 1 or 2 weeks, 4 weeks is generally preferred to allow the body sufficient time to adjust, especially in patients with additional risk factors for thromboembolism.

questions.text: All are steps of rapid sequence intubation except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Inhalational induction Rapid sequence intubation (RSI) is a procedure used to secure the airway quickly, especially in patients at risk of aspiration or those with difficult airways. It is designed to minimize aspiration risk and provide fast and efficient intubation. Inhalational induction (Choice C) is not a part of RSI. RSI typically involves the use of intravenous induction agents (like propofol or etomidate) for rapid sedation, followed by a neuromuscular blocker (such as succinylcholine) to facilitate intubation. Inhalational agents are slower in onset and not ideal for quick, secure airway management in RSI. Incorrect Answers: A. Preoxygenation for 3-5 min: Preoxygenation is a critical step in RSI, as it helps fill the patient's lungs with oxygen to maximize oxygen reserves and minimize desaturation during the procedure. This step is typically done for 3-5 minutes prior to intubation. B. Scoline (Succinylcholine) is the drug of choice: Succinylcholine (Scoline) is commonly used in RSI because of its rapid onset and short duration of action, making it ideal for facilitating quick intubation while providing muscle relaxation. D. Cricoid pressure is applied: Cricoid pressure, also known as the Sellick maneuver, is applied during RSI to prevent aspiration by compressing the esophagus and minimizing the risk of gastric regurgitation into the airway.

questions.text: Special vaporizer is required for
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Desflurane Desflurane requires a special vaporizer because of its low boiling point (22.8°C) and high vapor pressure at room temperature. This makes it necessary to use a vaporizer specifically designed for desflurane that can safely control the delivery of the anesthetic to the patient. Standard vaporizers cannot effectively deliver desflurane because they are not designed to handle its high volatility at normal temperatures. Incorrect Answers: A. Enflurane: Enflurane does not require a special vaporizer. It can be delivered using standard vaporizers, as its boiling point and vapor pressure are within the range that standard equipment can manage. C. Isoflurane: Isoflurane is similar to enflurane in that it does not require a special vaporizer. It is delivered using standard vaporizers that are commonly used in anesthesia. D. Halothane: Halothane also does not require a special vaporizer. Like isoflurane and enflurane, it is compatible with standard vaporizers used in clinical practice.

questions.text: Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Factors associated with a high risk of aspiration include: • Abdominal pathology, especially obstruction or ileus; • Delayed gastric emptying (e.g. pain, trauma, opioids, alcohol, vagotomy) • Incompetent lower oesophageal sphincter, hiatus hernia, gastrooesophageal reflux disease • Altered conscious level resulting in impaired laryngeal reflexes; • Neurological or neuromuscular disease • Pregnancy • Difficult airway • Metabolic disturbances.

choices.text: Occurs when temp. Falls below –6 degrees
Oxygen and nitrous oxide separates inside cylinder

questions.text: Poynting effect is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Entonox is stored in white or blue cylinders with blue and white shoulders. It is supplied in cylinders and must be stored above its pseudocritical temperature of -6°C. Below this temperature the N2O liquefies in a process called lamination. If this occurs a high concentration of O2 will be delivered first with little analgesic effect, but as the cylinder empties the mixture will become progressively more potent and hypoxic as it approaches 100% N2O. This effect is called as poynting effect.

questions.text: Oxygen carriage in smokers is improved if smoking is stopped … before surgery
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Effect of carbon monoxide and nicotine reverses in 12 – 24 hours after cessation of smoking and improves o2 carrying capacity of the lung. Stoppage for 4-6 weeks improves the bronchial and mucosal hyperactivity and small airway narrowing as well as ciliary function is improved Stoppage for 6 months or more brings the patient to pre smoking levels.

questions.text: Concerning LMA, one of the following is true
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A: LMA is inferior to endotracheal tube to prevent aspiration but superior to face mask Option B: LMA is easier to insert and ventilate in patients with difficult airway because it doesmot require direct laryngoscopy. Option C: ETT has more laryngeal irritation than LMA Option D: LMA is a very effective instrument of ventilation in users who are novoices so can beused by paramedical staff in emergency situations as well.

questions.text: 78 Year old patient with stable angina whose exercise capacity is limited to walking 200 feet before angina supervenes is in the ASA class of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • ASA I A normal healthy patient Healthy, non-smoking, no or minimal alcohol use • ASA II A patient with mild systemic disease Mild diseases only without substantive functional limitations. Examples include (but not limited to): current smoker, social alcohol drinker, pregnancy, obesity (30 3 months) of MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents. • ASA IV A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life Examples include (but not limited to): recent (< 3 months) MI, CVA, TIA, or CAD/stents, ongoing cardiac ischemia or severe valve dysfunction, severe reduction of ejection fraction, sepsis, DIC, ARD or ESRD not undergoing regularly scheduled dialysis • ASA V A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation Examples include (but not limited to): ruptured abdominal/ thoracic aneurysm, massive trauma, intracranial bleed with mass effect, ischemic bowel in the face of significant cardiac pathology or multiple organ/system dysfunction • ASA VI A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes * The addition of “E” denotes Emergency surgery:

questions.text: The pin index code for Nitrous oxide is–
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 3,5 The pin index code (PIC) system is used to ensure that gas cylinders are connected to the correct equipment by using a unique arrangement of pins. Each gas type has a specific pin index to prevent the accidental administration of the wrong gas. For Nitrous oxide (N2O), the pin index code is 3, 5. This means that the cylinder valve for nitrous oxide has pins in positions 3 and 5, which correspond to the gas type. Incorrect Answers: A. 2, 5: This is not the correct pin index code for any of the common gases used in anesthesia. Nitrous oxide does not use this combination. B. 2, 6: This is also not the pin index code for nitrous oxide. This combination is used for oxygen (O2). C. 1, 6: This pin index code is used for air, not nitrous oxide.

questions.text: Pre-anaesthetic medication is given to-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All of the above Pre-anaesthetic medication serves multiple purposes to ensure that the patient has a smoother experience during surgery. The key purposes of pre-anaesthetic medication include: Reduce anxiety and fear (A): Pre-anaesthetic medications, such as benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam, lorazepam), are often administered to alleviate pre-surgical anxiety and fear, ensuring the patient is calm and relaxed before the procedure. Reduction of secretion of saliva (B): Medications like anticholinergics (e.g., atropine, glycopyrrolate) are commonly used to reduce secretions (e.g., salivation) during surgery, especially when the patient is undergoing general anesthesia, to prevent aspiration and facilitate smooth intubation. To produce amnesia (C): Pre-anaesthetic medications like benzodiazepines are also used to induce anterograde amnesia, so the patient does not remember the events surrounding surgery, reducing the emotional and psychological trauma.

questions.text: The pressure required to inflate the cuff on an endotracheal tube is –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 15-25 mm Hg The pressure required to inflate the cuff on an endotracheal tube is typically between 15-25 mm Hg. This pressure range is sufficient to create a seal between the cuff and the tracheal wall while minimizing the risk of damaging the tracheal mucosa. It ensures an effective seal to prevent aspiration and maintain ventilation while reducing the risk of ischemic injury to the tracheal tissues. Incorrect Answers: A. 5-10 mm Hg: This pressure is too low to ensure an adequate seal of the cuff against the trachea, potentially leading to air leaks and inadequate ventilation. C. 30-45 mm Hg: This pressure is too high and could cause tracheal ischemia or damage to the tracheal mucosa if maintained for prolonged periods. D. 50-60 mm Hg: This pressure is excessively high and would significantly increase the risk of tracheal injury, mucosal necrosis, and other complications.

questions.text: To decrease awareness in general anaesthesia, the following is given-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option a: increasing the depth of anesthesia maintains the plane of anesthesia and prevents awareness Option b : more muscle relaxant increses the depth of muscle relaxation required for immobility during surgery. Option c: premedicate with morphine and atropine decreses the requirement of inductionagents and secrestions

questions.text: Blind nasal intubation is indicated in-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Indications of blind nasal intubation are: • Trismus or inability to open mouth or TM joint ankyloses • Dental procedures • Unstable cervical spine injury • Maxilla facial surgeries • Patients with intraoral mass In patients with mandibular fractures oro pharyngeal intubation actually becomes easy because of mobile mandible so 1st choice is always oral intubation

questions.text: What is the reasonable size for an endotracheal tube to be used in an average 3-year old child-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • Formula for size of tube in paediatric age group is Age \4+4 • So for a 3 year old the ID(internal diameter) of tube will be 4.75mm • Since tubes come in multiples of 0.5mm ID so we will use a tube of less size than 4.75, which is 4.5mm ID. • We prefer using uncuffed tube till 8 years of age.

questions.text: Sodium hydroxide in soda lime acts as–
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A catalyst In soda lime, sodium hydroxide (NaOH) acts as a catalyst in the process of absorbing carbon dioxide (CO2) during general anesthesia. The key components of soda lime include sodium hydroxide, calcium hydroxide, and potassium hydroxide, which are responsible for absorbing exhaled CO2. Sodium hydroxide enhances the efficiency of the reaction where CO2 is absorbed and converted to sodium carbonate, calcium carbonate, and water. Incorrect Answers: B. A humidifying agent: Sodium hydroxide is not a humidifying agent. Its primary function in soda lime is to assist in the absorption of carbon dioxide and is not related to adding moisture to the air or the gas mixture. C. An indicator: Soda lime may contain a pH indicator (such as phenolphthalein or thymolphthalein) that changes color when the absorbent material is exhausted, but sodium hydroxide itself is not the indicator. The indicator is used to signal when the soda lime is no longer effective at absorbing CO2. D. All of the above: Since sodium hydroxide acts primarily as a catalyst and not as a humidifying agent or indicator, (D) All of the above is incorrect.

questions.text: The Boyle machine is –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Boyles anesthesia machine is a continuous flow machine with the flow of carrier gas present at all times during the respiration. Option B : intermittent type machines are one in which gas flow occurs only during inspiration eg water two and fro canister Option c : draw over is a type of vaporizer Option d: temperature compensated is a type of vaporizer that compensates the temperature according to the vaporization of agents.

questions.text: Ayre’s T-piece breathing system is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mapleson E system The Ayre’s T-piece breathing system is classified as Mapleson E in the Mapleson classification of breathing systems. This system is used for spontaneous ventilation in patients, particularly in anesthesia and resuscitation settings. It consists of a simple T-shaped configuration with a fresh gas flow, an inspiratory limb, an expiratory limb, and a reservoir bag. It is primarily used in non-intubated patients, and the system allows for adequate gas exchange while minimizing dead space. Incorrect Answers: A. Mapleson A system: The Mapleson A system is a modified Ayre’s T-piece used for controlled or spontaneous ventilation, but it is not the same as Ayre's T-piece, which is specifically referred to as Mapleson E. B. Mapleson B system: Mapleson B involves a different configuration and is not the same as the Ayre's T-piece. It includes an expiratory valve and is not as widely used for spontaneous breathing. C. Mapleson D system: Mapleson D is another variant of breathing systems but differs from the Ayre's T-piece (Mapleson E) and is designed for different uses, often with a fresh gas supply from a reservoir bag.

questions.text: Soda lime contains-
questions.solution: Correct Answer: (B) 5% NaOH and 80% Ca(OH)2 Soda lime is a mixture used in anesthesia and respiratory therapy to absorb carbon dioxide (CO2) from exhaled gases. It primarily contains calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)2) and sodium hydroxide (NaOH). The most common formulation of soda lime consists of: 5% sodium hydroxide (NaOH): This helps to enhance the absorption process of CO2 by acting as a catalyst. 80% calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)2): This is the main substance responsible for absorbing CO2 in soda lime. The remaining percentage consists of water and inert materials like silica to prevent degradation and ensure the correct texture of the absorbent. Incorrect Answers: A. 5% Ca(OH)2 and 95% NaOH: This formulation is incorrect. While both calcium hydroxide and sodium hydroxide are present in soda lime, calcium hydroxide is the main component, and sodium hydroxide is present in much lower concentrations. C. 20% NaOH and 80% Ca(OH)2: This formulation is also incorrect because the concentration of NaOH is typically lower, around 5%, rather than 20%. D. 15% NaOH and 85% Ca(OH)2: This formulation is incorrect. While the ratio of NaOH and Ca(OH)2 might seem plausible, the typical concentration is around 5% NaOH and 80% Ca(OH)2, not 15% NaOH.

questions.text: Oxygen supply through pipe line from central gas, supply is at the pressure of-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 50 psi Oxygen supplied through a central pipeline system is delivered at a pressure of approximately 50 psi (pounds per square inch). This is the standard working pressure for medical gas pipelines and is regulated to ensure consistent and safe delivery of oxygen and other gases to anesthesia machines and other medical equipment. This pressure is optimal for most devices used in hospitals, as it provides a steady flow of gas without exceeding the equipment's operational limits. Incorrect Answers: A. 30 psi: A pressure of 30 psi is too low for medical gas systems and would not be sufficient to maintain the flow rates required for medical devices and anesthesia machines. C. 100 psi: A pressure of 100 psi is much higher than required for medical oxygen systems and could pose a safety risk by damaging equipment or creating leaks in the pipeline. D. 80 psi: While 80 psi is closer to the typical pipeline pressures for industrial applications, it is still higher than the standard medical gas pressure of 50 psi.

choices.text: The patient is accompanied home after the procedure
A heavy premedication is administered is administered if the patient is nervous
A blood sample for Hb is always taken
The patient is starved at least 2 hours for solid food prior to the procedure

questions.text: In assessing a patient for day care surgery, it is essential that –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A: patient needs to be accompanied by a relative after the discharge so that they can report back to hospital in case of emergency. Option B: light or no premedication is given to patients so that there is no post operative sedation. Option C: routine patients for day care surgery don’t need to undergo any preoperative investigations. Option D: the patients need to starved for 6 hours for solid food and 2 hours for clear liquids.

questions.text: In magill circuit fresh gas flow is–
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Equal to minute volume In the Magill circuit, which is part of the Mapleson A system, the fresh gas flow (FGF) is set to be equal to the minute volume of the patient during spontaneous breathing. The minute volume is the amount of air the patient breathes in or out per minute, calculated as: Minute Volume = Tidal Volume × Respiratory Rate This ensures that the patient receives sufficient fresh gas to meet their ventilation needs while also effectively removing exhaled carbon dioxide. The Magill circuit is efficient for spontaneous ventilation, as it requires lower fresh gas flow compared to other systems. Incorrect Answers: B. Twice the minute volume: Fresh gas flow being twice the minute volume is a feature of systems like the Mapleson D during controlled ventilation, not the Magill circuit. C. Equal to alveolar volume: The fresh gas flow in the Magill circuit is not limited to alveolar volume. The fresh gas flow matches the entire minute volume, which includes both the alveolar volume and dead space ventilation. D. Half the minute volume: Setting the fresh gas flow to half the minute volume would result in insufficient ventilation, leading to the rebreathing of carbon dioxide, which is not the case in a properly functioning Magill circuit.

choices.text: To check the size of tongue for laryngoscope
To check the movement of the cervical spine
To check the flexion and extension of the neck
To check the size of endotracheal tube

questions.text: Mallampatti test is used for –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) To check the size of tongue for laryngoscope The Mallampatti test is used to assess the ease of intubation and to predict potential difficulties in visualizing the larynx during endotracheal intubation. The test evaluates the visibility of the oral and pharyngeal structures, including the size of the tongue and the position of the uvula, which helps determine the difficulty of inserting the laryngoscope and passing the endotracheal tube. The Mallampatti classification system categorizes the visibility of the structures in the oral cavity and is used to predict the difficulty of intubation based on what is visible during the test. The more structures visible, the easier the intubation is likely to be. Incorrect Answers: B. To check the movement of the cervical spine: The Mallampatti test is not used for assessing the cervical spine movement. The cervical spine mobility is typically assessed using the C-spine examination in patients who may have neck injuries. C. To check the flexion and extension of the neck: This is also not the purpose of the Mallampatti test. The flexion and extension of the neck is assessed separately to evaluate the range of motion and potential difficulty in positioning the patient for intubation, but it is not a feature of the Mallampatti classification. D. To check the size of the endotracheal tube: The Mallampatti test does not assess the size of the endotracheal tube. The size of the tube is determined based on factors such as the patient's age, sex, and physical characteristics, but it is not part of the Mallampatti classification.

questions.text: In anaesthesia gas under pressure is stored in containers made of –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Molybdenum steel Gases used in anesthesia are stored in high-pressure containers made from molybdenum steel or alloy steel. Molybdenum steel is specifically used because it is strong, durable, and capable of withstanding the high pressures required for storing gases safely. It is resistant to corrosion and ensures the structural integrity of gas cylinders, which is critical for safety in medical and industrial settings. Incorrect Answers: A. Iron: While iron is a strong material, it is not commonly used for storing pressurized gases due to its susceptibility to rust and corrosion. It does not provide the same level of safety and durability as molybdenum steel. C. Copper: Copper is a good conductor of heat and electricity but is generally not used for storing pressurized gases. It is more prone to corrosion and doesn't have the strength or durability needed for pressurized containers. D. Alloy of iron and copper: An alloy of iron and copper is not typically used for pressurized gas storage, as it doesn't provide the same strength and corrosion resistance as molybdenum steel. While copper can be part of alloys, molybdenum steel is the preferred material for this purpose.

questions.text: An anaesthetist orders a new attendant to bring the oxygen cylinder. He will ask the attendant to identify the correct cylinder by the following color code –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Black cylinder with white shoulders In the color coding system for medical gas cylinders, the oxygen cylinder is typically black with white shoulders. This color code is used internationally to easily identify oxygen cylinders, ensuring safety and preventing errors when handling or administering gases in a medical setting. Black with white shoulders signifies that the cylinder contains oxygen (O2), which is one of the most commonly used gases in anesthesia and critical care. Incorrect Answers: B. Black cylinders with grey shoulders: This color code is used for carbon dioxide (CO2) cylinders, not oxygen. C. White cylinders with black shoulders: This color code is not used for any standard medical gas cylinder. It does not correspond to oxygen or any other common medical gas. D. Grey cylinders with white shoulders: This color code typically indicates nitrous oxide (N2O) cylinders, not oxygen.

choices.text: Incorrect attachment of anaesthesia face masks

questions.text: Pin index system is a safety feature adopted in anaesthesia. Machines to prevent-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) PIN INDEX SAFETY SYSTEM ( PISS) It is a set of pins on the neck of the cylinder and corresponding holes (indexes) in the hanger yoke assembly of the anesthesia machine. Every gas has a specific set of pins and indexes and so a cylinder of one gas cannot be attached to the hub of another gas in the machine thus providing a safety feature against wrong attachment of cylinder to machine.

questions.text: The physiological dead space is decreased by-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Neck flexion Neck flexion can help decrease physiological dead space by improving ventilation-perfusion matching in the lungs. When the neck is flexed, the position can optimize the airway alignment and enhance the flow of air to the lower, more perfused regions of the lungs, thereby reducing dead space. This effect occurs due to improved airway dynamics and better distribution of airflow, which is beneficial in certain clinical situations. Incorrect Answers: A. Upright position: The upright position generally increases physiological dead space. In this position, the blood flow to the upper parts of the lungs (which are less perfused) may increase the ventilation-perfusion mismatch, leading to increased dead space. It is not a position that decreases dead space. B. Positive pressure ventilation: Positive pressure ventilation (e.g., during mechanical ventilation) tends to increase dead space because it can reduce the efficiency of ventilation to certain lung areas, particularly in the presence of lung pathology, leading to less effective perfusion and ventilation matching. D. Emphysema: Emphysema is a type of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) that leads to destruction of the alveolar walls and loss of lung elasticity, which actually increases physiological dead space. In emphysema, air is trapped in the damaged alveolar regions, reducing the effective surface area for gas exchange, thus increasing dead space.

questions.text: In a normal adult a breath holding time below …… indicates lack of cardiorespiratory reserve-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 20 seconds In a normal adult, the ability to hold their breath is a good indicator of cardiorespiratory reserve. A breath-holding time of less than 20 seconds is generally considered to indicate a lack of adequate cardiorespiratory reserve. This is because it suggests that the body may not be able to efficiently oxygenate the blood or manage CO2 buildup, which could be a sign of impaired lung function or cardiac reserve. Incorrect Answers: A. 8 seconds: A breath-holding time of 8 seconds is much too short and would indicate a severe lack of cardiorespiratory reserve, which is typically not observed in healthy adults. B. 10 seconds: A breath-holding time of 10 seconds may indicate mild impairment but is still not typically used as a definitive cutoff for a lack of cardiorespiratory reserve in normal adults. D. 18 seconds: A breath-holding time of 18 seconds may also suggest some limitation in cardiorespiratory reserve, but it is still within a range that would generally be considered to be relatively normal, although it may be closer to the threshold of reduced reserve.

questions.text: Drugs which does not cross blood brain barrier-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Neostigmine Neostigmine is a quaternary ammonium compound, which means it has a charged structure that prevents it from crossing the blood-brain barrier (BBB). It works peripherally by inhibiting the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, increasing the availability of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. Since it cannot cross the BBB, it does not have central nervous system (CNS) effects. Incorrect Answers: B. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is a tertiary amine, which allows it to cross the blood-brain barrier and have both peripheral and central effects. It is used to treat conditions like anticholinergic toxicity because it can reverse the effects of drugs that block acetylcholine receptors in the brain. C. Atropine: Atropine is another tertiary amine that crosses the blood-brain barrier. It has both peripheral and central effects, such as increasing heart rate and dilating the pupils, and can have central side effects like delirium or agitation when used at high doses. D. Hyoscine (Scopolamine): Hyoscine (or scopolamine) is a tertiary amine and, like atropine, crosses the blood-brain barrier. It has CNS effects and is used to treat motion sickness or nausea by acting on the central nervous system.

questions.text: Elective surgery in a patient who had a myocardial infarction is best done after-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) 6 months Elective surgery in a patient who has had a myocardial infarction (MI) is generally best performed after a period of 6 months. This waiting period allows for the stabilization of the heart and ensures that the patient has had enough time for cardiac rehabilitation. After 6 months, the patient is typically in a better condition to tolerate surgery, as there is a lower risk of perioperative complications related to cardiac events. Additionally, by this time, the patient may have recovered from the acute effects of the MI and can better withstand the stress of surgery. Incorrect Answers: A. 2 months: 2 months is considered too soon after an MI for elective surgery. The patient may still be at high risk of experiencing further cardiac events, such as another MI or arrhythmias, during or after surgery. B. 3 months: 3 months might be acceptable for certain patients, but 6 months is the more commonly recommended time frame for optimal recovery and stabilization. C. 5 months: 5 months is still considered a shorter recovery period, and while some patients may tolerate surgery at this stage, it does not offer the same level of cardiac stabilization as 6 months would.

questions.text: The narrowest part of larynx in a newborn is at the level of –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cricoid In a newborn, the narrowest part of the larynx is at the level of the cricoid cartilage. This is important for airway management, as the cricoid is located just below the vocal cords and forms a narrow, rigid ring. Unlike in adults, where the narrowest part of the airway is at the level of the vocal cords, the cricoid cartilage is the most constricted part of the larynx in infants, making it a key anatomical feature to consider during intubation and airway management in pediatric patients. Incorrect Answers: B. Thyroid: The thyroid cartilage is located above the cricoid and is part of the larger structure of the larynx. It is not the narrowest part of the larynx in newborns. C. Vocal cords: In newborns, the vocal cords are not the narrowest part of the larynx. In adults, the vocal cords are the narrowest part, but in infants, it is the cricoid cartilage. D. Arytenoid: The arytenoid cartilages are involved in the movement of the vocal cords but do not represent the narrowest part of the larynx in newborns.

questions.text: Anatomical dead space is increased in all except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Massive pleural effusion Anatomical dead space refers to the portion of the respiratory system where gas exchange does not occur. It includes the nose, pharynx, trachea, and bronchi. In general, anatomical dead space increases with conditions that impair gas exchange or restrict the flow of air to the alveoli. Massive pleural effusion typically does not increase anatomical dead space directly. While it can cause lung compression and impair ventilation and perfusion, it does not affect the conducting airways (the anatomical dead space), which remains the same. Instead, pleural effusion primarily impacts the physiological dead space, which involves the areas of the lung where ventilation is ineffective due to ventilation-perfusion mismatch. Incorrect Answers: B. Inspiration: During inspiration, the anatomical dead space temporarily increases because of the movement of air into the conducting airways. However, this increase is very transient and is not a long-term increase in dead space. C. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that causes bronchodilation and decreases secretions. While it can affect the airway by dilating the bronchial passages, it does not affect anatomical dead space significantly. However, the drug can increase airway resistance, which may impact ventilation, potentially causing an increase in physiological dead space (although not anatomical dead space per se). D. Halothane: Halothane is a volatile anesthetic that can decrease airway resistance and cause bronchodilation. It doesn't directly increase anatomical dead space but may cause a slight increase in physiological dead space by affecting ventilation-perfusion matching, particularly in compromised lung function.

questions.text: 16th October is celebrated as –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ether day 16th October is celebrated as Ether Day. This day marks the anniversary of the first successful public demonstration of ether anesthesia in 1846, performed by William T.G. Morton at the Massachusetts General Hospital. This was a significant milestone in the history of anesthesia, as it demonstrated the use of ether for general anesthesia during surgery, revolutionizing the field of surgery and anesthesia. Incorrect Answers: B. Chloroform day: Chloroform was introduced as an anesthetic agent after ether, but Chloroform Day is not specifically celebrated on 16th October. Chloroform became widely used as an anesthetic in the 19th century, but it is associated with risks, especially with its use in childbirth. C. Halothane day: Halothane is a volatile anesthetic introduced in the 1950s, but Halothane Day is not specifically celebrated. It became an important anesthetic in the 20th century but does not have a designated celebration like Ether Day. D. Cyclopropane day: Cyclopropane was once used as an anesthetic agent, but there is no specific Cyclopropane Day. It was largely replaced due to safety concerns.

questions.text: A 25 years male is under going incison and drainage of abscess under general anesthesia with spontaneous resp.the most efficient circuit is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mapleson A In a patient undergoing incision and drainage of an abscess under general anesthesia with spontaneous respiration, the Mapleson A circuit is the most efficient. This circuit is a non-rebreathing system that allows for the delivery of fresh gas directly to the patient's lungs while effectively removing exhaled gases. It is often preferred for spontaneous ventilation because it provides minimal resistance to the patient’s breathing efforts, ensuring efficient ventilation. The Mapleson A circuit is designed to minimize dead space and allow for the easy elimination of carbon dioxide, making it ideal for patients who are breathing on their own. Incorrect Answers: B. Mapleson B: The Mapleson B circuit is similar to the A circuit but with the fresh gas inlet placed closer to the patient’s airway. It is less efficient than Mapleson A, especially in the case of spontaneous breathing. C. Mapleson C: The Mapleson C circuit is another modification but not as efficient for spontaneous breathing as the Mapleson A. It has a fresh gas inlet and an adjustable valve for controlling exhalation, but it is better suited for controlled ventilation rather than spontaneous ventilation. D. Mapleson D: The Mapleson D circuit is useful for controlled ventilation, but it is less efficient than Mapleson A for spontaneous ventilation. It has a fresh gas inlet at the patient end and requires more flow to clear CO2.

questions.text: Oxygen is given during anesthesia to prevent:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hypoxia Oxygen is administered during anesthesia primarily to prevent hypoxia (a condition where there is insufficient oxygen in the tissues). Anesthesia can impair normal respiratory function by reducing the drive to breathe and altering ventilation-perfusion matching in the lungs. By providing supplemental oxygen, the risk of hypoxia is minimized, ensuring that the patient receives adequate oxygenation throughout the procedure. Incorrect Answers: A. Pain: Oxygen is not given to relieve pain during anesthesia. Anesthesia agents, including analgesics, are used to manage pain during surgery. Oxygen helps with oxygenation, but it does not directly address pain relief. C. Hypercapnia: Although hypercapnia (elevated carbon dioxide levels) can occur during anesthesia, oxygen is not specifically given to prevent hypercapnia. Instead, ventilation (either spontaneous or assisted) and careful monitoring are used to manage carbon dioxide levels. D. Hypotension: Oxygen does not directly prevent hypotension (low blood pressure), although adequate oxygenation can support cardiovascular function and improve the overall perfusion of vital organs. Hypotension is typically managed with intravenous fluids, vasopressors, or adjustments to the anesthesia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a definitive airway?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Laryngeal mask airway (LMA) A definitive airway refers to an airway device that provides a secure and permanent way to control the patient's airway and facilitate ventilation. Tracheostomy, orotracheal tube, and nasotracheal tube are all considered definitive airways because they provide direct access to the trachea for long-term ventilation and airway management. However, the Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA) is not considered a definitive airway. While it is used to secure the airway in many situations (especially in short-term procedures or as a rescue device), it does not provide as secure a connection to the trachea as the other options. The LMA sits over the laryngeal inlet and provides a seal but does not guarantee a completely protected airway in the same way as a tracheal tube or tracheostomy. Incorrect Answers: A. Tracheostomy: A tracheostomy is a definitive airway that involves creating an opening in the trachea through which a tube is inserted to secure the airway. It is typically used for long-term airway management in patients with prolonged respiratory issues. B. Orotracheal tube: An orotracheal tube is a definitive airway inserted through the mouth into the trachea to secure the airway and facilitate mechanical ventilation. C. Nasotracheal tube: A nasotracheal tube is also a definitive airway, inserted through the nose into the trachea, commonly used when oral intubation is not possible or desirable.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding colour coding of anaesthetic gases?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Nitrous oxide - Blue In the color coding system for medical gases, each gas is assigned a specific color to help differentiate it for safety and ease of use. Here are the correct associations: Nitrous oxide is represented by the blue cylinder color in the standard color-coding system for medical gases. Oxygen is represented by a green cylinder (not black with grey shoulders as suggested in option A). Cyclopropane is represented by a red cylinder (not blue as suggested in option C). Helium is represented by a brown cylinder (not orange as suggested in option D). Incorrect Answers: A. Oxygen - Black with grey shoulders: This is incorrect. The correct color coding for oxygen is green (or white in some countries, but not black with grey shoulders). C. Cyclopropane - Red: While cyclopropane is indeed represented by a red cylinder, the color coding for nitrous oxide is the correct part of the question here, and the other options are also incorrect. D. Helium - Orange: The color for helium cylinders is brown, not orange.

choices.text: Jackson Rees modification of Ayre T piece

questions.text: The most appropriate circuit for ventilating spontaneously breathing infant during anaesthesia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Jackson Rees modification of Ayre T piece The Jackson Rees modification of Ayre T-piece is the most appropriate circuit for ventilating a spontaneously breathing infant during anesthesia. This system is commonly used for pediatric patients, especially infants, because it is a non-rebreathing circuit that allows fresh gas to flow directly to the patient, and exhaled gases are vented through an open end. It minimizes resistance to the infant’s breathing efforts, ensuring efficient ventilation and oxygenation during anesthesia. Incorrect Answers: B. Mapleson A or Magill circuit: While the Mapleson A (Magill circuit) can be used for spontaneous ventilation, it is typically more appropriate for adult patients and may not be as effective for small infants, who have a smaller airway and are more prone to airway resistance. It also does not provide as efficient a method of preventing rebreathing, making it less ideal for this patient group compared to the Jackson Rees modification of the Ayre T-piece. C. Mapleson C: The Mapleson C circuit is typically used for controlled ventilation and is not the most suitable option for spontaneously breathing infants. It is better suited for adults or for controlled ventilation in pediatric patients. D. Closed circuit with sodalime: A closed circuit with sodalime is typically used for controlled ventilation and is often utilized for longer surgical procedures. However, it is not ideal for spontaneously breathing infants, as it may create more resistance and is not the best option for maintaining spontaneous breathing.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for endotracheal intubation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pneumothorax Pneumothorax is not an indication for endotracheal intubation. Pneumothorax refers to the presence of air in the pleural space that can lead to lung collapse. While it requires urgent management, such as needle decompression or chest tube insertion, it does not necessitate endotracheal intubation. Intubation in the case of pneumothorax would only be considered if there is concurrent respiratory failure or if the pneumothorax leads to significant difficulty in breathing. Incorrect Answers: A. Maintenance of a patent airway: Endotracheal intubation is commonly used to secure and maintain a patent airway, particularly in unconscious or critically ill patients. Intubation ensures that the airway remains open and clear of obstructions, which is vital during surgeries or emergencies. B. To provide positive pressure ventilation: Endotracheal intubation is often used to provide positive pressure ventilation during anesthesia or in patients who cannot breathe effectively on their own. This allows the delivery of oxygen and removal of carbon dioxide. C. Pulmonary toilet: Pulmonary toilet refers to the clearing of secretions or fluids from the lungs (such as in patients with excessive mucus or during post-operative recovery). Endotracheal intubation is often necessary in patients requiring mechanical ventilation and pulmonary toilet to manage airway secretions effectively.

choices.text: More movement or displacement of endotracheal tube

questions.text: Merits of nasotracheal intubation is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Good oral hygiene One of the merits of nasotracheal intubation is that it allows for better oral hygiene compared to orotracheal intubation. The tube passes through the nose rather than the mouth, which means it does not obstruct the oral cavity, making it easier for healthcare providers to maintain oral care and perform procedures like suctioning or cleaning the mouth and teeth during surgery or prolonged ventilation. Incorrect Answers: B. Less infection: Nasotracheal intubation does not necessarily reduce the risk of infection. In fact, nasotracheal intubation can sometimes increase the risk of sinus infections or nasal and upper respiratory tract infections due to the introduction of a foreign object through the nasal passages. C. Less mucosal damage and bleeding: While nasotracheal intubation can sometimes be associated with less oral trauma, it can lead to more mucosal damage and bleeding in the nasal passages and upper airway due to the relatively smaller size of the nasal passage compared to the mouth. In certain cases, nasal intubation can cause nasal trauma, including epistaxis (nosebleeds). D. More movement or displacement of endotracheal tube: In fact, nasotracheal intubation generally provides more stability compared to orotracheal intubation, as the tube is secured through the nose, and there is less likelihood of displacement. This can be beneficial in certain surgeries, especially in oral or maxillofacial procedures.

questions.text: In a cervical spine injury which is most effective in least movement at C1C2 during layrngoscopy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Manual in-line stabilization In the case of cervical spine injury, manual in-line stabilization is the most effective technique for minimizing movement at the C1-C2 level during laryngoscopy. This technique involves physically stabilizing the head and neck in a neutral position to prevent any excessive movement of the cervical spine during the procedure. The goal is to maintain the alignment of the cervical vertebrae and prevent further injury to the spinal cord during intubation. The manual in-line stabilization technique is considered the gold standard in preventing movement of the cervical spine at C1-C2 during intubation in patients with suspected spinal injury. Incorrect Answers: B. Axial traction: Axial traction is generally used for spinal decompression and may not be appropriate during laryngoscopy. It can apply additional forces on the spine, potentially causing movement at C1-C2, which should be avoided in cervical spine injury. C. Sandbags: Sandbags are often used for positioning and stabilization of the head and neck but are less effective than manual in-line stabilization. They do not provide the same level of control over head and neck movement during laryngoscopy. D. Hard collar: A hard collar can help provide some level of neck stabilization, but it may not provide enough protection or restriction of movement at the C1-C2 level during laryngoscopy. It is not as effective as manual in-line stabilization in minimizing movement during the procedure.

choices.text: Can be used to regulate gas flow
Can convert gas at high pressure to low pressure

questions.text: Pressure gauge: true is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Works on Bourdon principle A pressure gauge typically works on the Bourdon principle, which is a mechanism used to measure pressure. It consists of a curved tube that straightens as the internal pressure increases. The straightening of the tube is then used to drive a needle on a dial, indicating the pressure. This principle is commonly used in pressure gauges for medical gas systems, such as oxygen tanks and anesthesia equipment. Incorrect Answers: B. Can be used to regulate gas flow: A pressure gauge does not regulate gas flow. It measures the pressure of the gas within a system. Flow regulators or flowmeters are the devices used to regulate the flow of gas. C. Can convert gas at high pressure to low pressure: A pressure gauge does not convert high pressure to low pressure. The function of converting high-pressure gas to low-pressure gas is performed by a pressure regulator. D. Form part of flowmeter: While a pressure gauge is often associated with flowmeters, it does not form part of them. A flowmeter is used to measure and regulate the flow rate of a gas, whereas the pressure gauge simply measures the pressure within a system. However, they can be found together in certain systems for monitoring purposes.

choices.text: Esophagus being pressed onto the vertebral body

questions.text: Success of cricoid pressure in preventing aspiration depends upon, false is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pre-oxygenation for 5 min The success of cricoid pressure in preventing aspiration is not dependent on pre-oxygenation for 5 minutes. While pre-oxygenation helps to increase the oxygen reserve before anesthesia induction, it does not directly influence the effectiveness of cricoid pressure in preventing aspiration. Cricoid pressure is applied to compress the esophagus against the vertebral body to prevent regurgitation and aspiration of stomach contents into the airway during anesthesia. Incorrect Answers: A. Absence of nasogastric tube: The presence of a nasogastric tube increases the risk of aspiration because it can provide a direct path for gastric contents to enter the airway. The absence of a nasogastric tube is an important factor in the effectiveness of cricoid pressure, as it reduces the risk of aspiration. B. Intact cricoid cartilage: The intact cricoid cartilage is essential for cricoid pressure to be effective. The pressure is applied to the cricoid cartilage to compress the esophagus and prevent aspiration. If the cricoid cartilage is damaged or absent, the cricoid pressure may not work as effectively. C. Esophagus being pressed onto the vertebral body: For cricoid pressure to be effective, the esophagus must be compressed against the vertebral body to prevent regurgitation of gastric contents into the airway. This is the key mechanism by which cricoid pressure prevents aspiration.

choices.text: ASA class II would include well controlled asthmatic
ASA class IV indicates a condition which impedes activity but not represent threat to life.
Post script ‘E’ indicates an elective case.

questions.text: The American Society of Anaesthesiologist, physical status:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) • The ASA physical status classification represents a widely used method of classifying the severity of coexisting disease among surgical patients. • Offers a general assessment of the severity and extent of a patient’s coexisting illnesses • Higher ASA physical status class can be corelated to higher post-operative mortality. • Drawbacks of ASA physical status classification is that it’s a subjective assessment and there is a gross inter observer bias and it doesn’t consider the risk associated with the type of surgery. • It therefore doesn’t predict post-operative surgical outcome in patients.

choices.text: Float should be on regular move

questions.text: Which is not true regarding flowmeters
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Oxygen should be upstream The statement that "Oxygen should be upstream" is not true regarding flowmeters. In fact, oxygen does not necessarily need to be placed upstream of other gases. In a typical flowmeter setup, oxygen can be supplied either upstream or downstream of other gases, depending on the design of the system, and the flowmeters are generally designed to regulate each gas independently. What is most important is that each gas flowmeter is set correctly for its specific gas and operates within the right parameters. Incorrect Answers: B. Float should be on regular move: This is true. The float inside the flowmeter should be in motion to indicate the flow of gas. It should float freely and move smoothly along the scale, indicating the actual flow rate of the gas. C. Must indicate gas color code/name: This is true. The flowmeter should clearly indicate the gas color code and the name of the gas to avoid confusion, ensuring the correct gas is being delivered. D. Float may stick with dust: This is true. The float in a flowmeter can stick or become stuck due to dust or contaminants. This can interfere with the accurate measurement of gas flow. It is important to regularly clean and maintain the flowmeter to avoid this issue.

choices.text: An eye piece of video laryngoscope
Equipment used to visualize larynx in difficult intubation

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Murphy eye
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Lateral opening on endotracheal tube The Murphy eye is a lateral opening located near the distal end of an endotracheal tube (ETT). This secondary opening is designed to allow for ventilation if the main opening of the tube becomes obstructed (for example, if the tube tip gets blocked against the tracheal wall). It provides a backup airway pathway, enhancing the safety of the airway management. Incorrect Answers: A. An eye piece of video laryngoscope: This is incorrect. The Murphy eye is not related to a video laryngoscope. It refers specifically to the lateral opening on an endotracheal tube, not to any part of a video laryngoscope system. C. Equipment used to visualize larynx in difficult intubation: This is also incorrect. The Murphy eye is not used for visualizing the larynx. It is a feature of the endotracheal tube, which helps maintain airway patency during intubation, particularly if the tube tip becomes blocked. D. Eye reaction to light: This is incorrect. The term "Murphy eye" is unrelated to the reaction of the eye to light. It refers to the secondary opening on the endotracheal tube, as mentioned above.

questions.text: All the following are discontinued before surgery except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Steroids Steroids (especially corticosteroids) are often not discontinued before surgery. In fact, patients who are on long-term steroid therapy may need to continue their medications or even have their dosage adjusted before surgery to avoid adrenal insufficiency and ensure proper stress response during surgery. Sudden discontinuation of steroids in patients who have been on chronic therapy can lead to adrenal crisis, which can be life-threatening. Incorrect Answers: A. Oral contraceptives: Oral contraceptives are usually discontinued before surgery, particularly in patients who are at increased risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE). The use of oral contraceptives can increase the risk of thromboembolic events, especially during periods of immobilization or surgery. C. Warfarin: Warfarin is typically discontinued before surgery because it is an anticoagulant. Continuing warfarin therapy increases the risk of bleeding complications during surgery. It is usually stopped several days before surgery, and bridging therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin may be used in some cases. D. Lithium: Lithium is usually discontinued before surgery because it can interact with anesthesia agents and may cause complications such as electrolyte imbalances. Patients on lithium therapy often require a temporary substitution with other medications during surgery.

questions.text: difficult intubation is suspected in all the following except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Sternomental distance >12.5 cm A sternomental distance greater than 12.5 cm is actually a favorable sign and suggests easier intubation. The sternomental distance refers to the distance between the manubrium (upper part of the sternum) and the mental prominence (chin). A greater distance indicates that there is sufficient space for the laryngoscope and endotracheal tube during intubation, and it is typically associated with easier visualization of the airway. Incorrect Answers: A. Mallampati grade 4: Mallampati grade 4 is associated with a difficult airway. This grade is characterized by the inability to see the uvula or any part of the pharynx, indicating that intubation may be difficult due to poor visualization of the airway structures. B. Thyromental distance <6.5 cm: A thyromental distance of less than 6.5 cm is a sign of possible difficult intubation. This distance is measured from the thyroid cartilage to the mental prominence (chin). A shorter distance suggests limited mobility of the neck and reduced space for intubation. C. Receding mandible: A receding mandible (or retrognathia) is also associated with difficult intubation. It can make it harder to visualize the glottis during laryngoscopy, leading to increased difficulty with intubation.

choices.text: Level of vocal cords is narrowest part of child’s airway
Best estimation of ETT size of a child correlates with child’s weight
An ETT which fits snugly through the vocal cords is right size for child
d) Size 3 lma is for 30 KG patient

questions.text: Which is correct
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A: narrowest part of a child’s airway is sub glottic \ cricoid. Option B: best estimation of ETT size in a child is by his age. Option C: In infants or young children, a tracheal tube that easily passes the vocal cords may be tight in the subglottic region because of the relatively greater proportional narrowing at the level of the cricoid cartilage. Thus uncuffed tracheal tubes were in the past preferred for children younger than 6 years of age. Nonetheless, a leak should be maintained around the cuff (with or without inflation) because injury to the tracheal mucosa is still possible. Option D: size 3 can be used in a patient of 30 kg

questions.text: Contraindication to blind nasal intubation include all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Spontaneous breathing Spontaneous breathing is not a contraindication to blind nasal intubation. In fact, spontaneous breathing is often maintained during nasal intubation, and in some cases, it can help ensure that the patient is adequately oxygenated during the procedure. Blind nasal intubation can be performed on spontaneously breathing patients, though it is often done under anesthesia or with sedation. Incorrect Answers: B. Base of skull fracture (Base of skull #): A base of skull fracture is a contraindication to blind nasal intubation. Nasal intubation can potentially lead to injury of the nasal cavity or the sinuses, and in the case of a base of skull fracture, it can result in the placement of the tube into the cranial cavity or aspiration of brain matter. This makes blind nasal intubation dangerous in patients with a suspected base of skull fracture. C. Coagulopathy: Coagulopathy (a condition in which the blood's ability to clot is impaired) is another contraindication to blind nasal intubation. Due to the fragile blood vessels in the nasal cavity and sinuses, nasal intubation can cause significant bleeding in patients with coagulopathy, making the procedure risky. D. Maxillary fracture (Maxillary #): A maxillary fracture is also a contraindication to blind nasal intubation. The trauma to the maxilla can cause misalignment and make it difficult to guide the tube correctly through the nasal passage, potentially leading to further injury and complications during intubation.

questions.text: In difficult airway algorithm Plan B involves
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) LMA In the difficult airway algorithm, Plan B typically involves the use of a Laryngeal Mask Airway (LMA). If endotracheal intubation is difficult or impossible using conventional methods (e.g., direct laryngoscopy), the LMA is a useful alternative for airway management. The LMA provides a secure airway and can be used for ventilation in situations where intubation is challenging. It is commonly used as part of Plan B when other methods fail to secure the airway. Incorrect Answers: B. Return to spontaneous ventilation: Return to spontaneous ventilation is generally part of the Plan C in the difficult airway algorithm, which involves considering the possibility of extubating the patient or allowing them to breathe on their own if intubation proves impossible. However, this is not part of Plan B. C. Awake the patient: This is not a standard component of Plan B. Awakening the patient may be considered if all other options fail (for example, if Plan A and Plan B fail), and it might be part of Plan C. However, the goal is to manage the airway with the least invasive and safest approach, which is where the LMA comes in during Plan B. D. Awake fiberoptic intubation: Awake fiberoptic intubation is typically considered a part of Plan A for managing a difficult airway, especially when the patient is awake and can tolerate the procedure. It is not generally used in Plan B, which is focused on airway maintenance with simpler, quicker techniques.

questions.text: Not a complication of intubation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hypotension Hypotension is not a direct complication of intubation. Although hypotension may occur during anesthesia due to other factors (such as anesthesia agents, blood loss, or vasodilation), it is not typically caused directly by the act of intubation itself. Intubation primarily affects the airway and breathing, not directly the cardiovascular system. Incorrect Answers: A. Dislocated mandible: Dislocated mandible can be a complication of intubation if excessive force is applied during the procedure, especially during mouth opening or laryngoscopy. This can occur in patients with increased jaw tension or those with pre-existing jaw problems. C. Laryngospasm: Laryngospasm is a common complication of intubation. It involves a reflex contraction of the vocal cords and can occur during or after intubation, especially in response to irritation of the airway. This can cause difficulty in breathing and is an important consideration during airway management. D. Negative pressure pulmonary edema: Negative pressure pulmonary edema (NPPE) is a serious complication that can occur during intubation, especially when there is a complete airway obstruction (e.g., during extubation or accidental dislodgment of the tube). It results from a sudden increase in negative pressure in the chest during efforts to breathe against an obstructed airway.

questions.text: reusable endotracheal tube best sterlised by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ethylene Oxide Ethylene oxide (EtO) is a low-temperature sterilization method that is ideal for heat- and moisture-sensitive medical equipment like endotracheal tubes. It works by disrupting the DNA and proteins of microorganisms, effectively sterilizing equipment without causing thermal damage. It is widely used for sterilizing complex instruments with narrow lumens, which are challenging to sterilize using other methods. Advantages: Non-corrosive to delicate materials like plastics and rubber. Effective against all types of microorganisms, including spores. Penetrates deep into equipment with narrow or complex lumens. Incorrect Options: A. Dry Heat Dry heat sterilization is unsuitable for endotracheal tubes because it involves high temperatures (typically 160–180°C for 2 hours), which can damage the plastic or rubber components of the tubes. This method is better suited for metal instruments and glassware. B. Formaldehyde Formaldehyde is used in low-temperature chemical sterilization but is less effective and less commonly used for medical devices. It also has a strong odor, is less safe to handle, and requires prolonged exposure, making it less practical compared to EtO. D. Phenol Phenol is a disinfectant, not a sterilizing agent. It can kill bacteria and viruses but does not eliminate spores, making it unsuitable for sterilization. Moreover, phenol is not recommended for medical devices because it can leave harmful residues.

questions.text: which of the following is kept in cylinders as compressed gas
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Air Air is a mixture of gases (primarily nitrogen and oxygen) that is stored in cylinders in a compressed gaseous form. It is used in various medical and industrial applications, such as providing breathable air during surgeries and in ventilators. Air does not undergo liquefaction at normal storage pressures and temperatures, making it suitable to be stored as compressed gas. Cylinders containing compressed air are marked accordingly, and pressure gauges are used to monitor the amount of gas remaining. Incorrect Options: A. Cyclopropane Cyclopropane, an anesthetic gas, is stored in cylinders as a liquefied gas rather than a compressed gas. This is because it can be liquefied under pressure at room temperature, allowing more of the gas to be stored in a smaller volume. It is not kept in the gaseous state under compression. B. Carbon dioxide Carbon dioxide is also stored in cylinders as a liquefied gas because it can easily transition to the liquid phase under pressure. Storing it in liquid form allows for more efficient storage, as liquid occupies less space compared to gas. C. Nitrous oxide Nitrous oxide is stored in cylinders as a liquefied gas under pressure. Like carbon dioxide, it liquefies easily under pressure, making it more compact and practical for storage. When the cylinder valve is opened, the liquid nitrous oxide evaporates to produce the gaseous form for use.

choices.text: Shift of oxy Hb dissociation curve to right

questions.text: Cessation of smoking 48 hours before surgery produce all the following, except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Effect of carbon monoxide and nicotine reverses in 12 – 24 hours after cessation of smoking and improves o2 carrying capacity of the lung, shifts the oxyhb dissociation curve to right thereby increasing tissue oxygen availability. Stoppage for 4-6 weeks improves the bronchial and mucosal hyperactivity and small airway narrowing as well as ciliary function is improved Stoppage for 6 months or more brings the patient to pre smoking levels.

questions.text: Time for desaturation to occur following the onset of apnea is influenced by the following:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Efficiency of preoxygenation The time for desaturation to occur following the onset of apnea is most significantly influenced by the efficiency of preoxygenation. Preoxygenation increases the body’s oxygen reserves, particularly in the lungs, by replacing nitrogen in the functional residual capacity (FRC) with oxygen. Efficient preoxygenation extends the duration of oxygen supply during apnea, delaying desaturation. Incorrect Options: A. Thyroid state of patient While thyroid disorders can influence metabolic rate (hyperthyroidism increases and hypothyroidism decreases oxygen consumption), the effect on time to desaturation is relatively minor compared to the impact of preoxygenation. Thus, this is not the most critical factor. C. Muscle relaxant used The muscle relaxant type does not directly affect oxygen desaturation time. However, some muscle relaxants may contribute to faster or slower respiratory muscle relaxation, indirectly influencing preoxygenation efficiency. Nevertheless, this is less significant than the role of preoxygenation itself. D. Age of the patient Age can influence oxygen consumption and lung capacity, with children having smaller FRC and higher oxygen consumption, leading to faster desaturation. However, efficient preoxygenation can still significantly mitigate this effect. Hence, age is a secondary factor compared to the efficiency of preoxygenation.

choices.text: Produces lengthening of neck esp in short neck pts
Should be done slowly and smoothly in pts of suspected cervical spine injury
Attempts to align thyroglossal and glossomental axis to improve intubating view
Attempt to align oral-pharynegeal and laryngeal axis to improve intubating view

questions.text: Placing the patient in sniffing position:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Attempt to align oral-pharyngeal and laryngeal axis to improve intubating view The sniffing position is a head and neck alignment technique used to optimize the view of the glottis during intubation. This position aligns the oral, pharyngeal, and laryngeal axes, creating a nearly straight path for the laryngoscope blade and improving visualization of the vocal cords. It involves flexion of the neck and extension of the head at the atlanto-occipital joint, often described as a slight "sniffing" posture. Incorrect Options: A. Produces lengthening of neck especially in short-neck patients The sniffing position does not lengthen the neck but instead helps improve alignment of the axes. While it may aid intubation in short-necked patients by optimizing the airway anatomy, it does not structurally "lengthen" the neck. B. Should be done slowly and smoothly in patients with suspected cervical spine injury In patients with suspected cervical spine injury, sniffing position is contraindicated, as it involves neck movement that could worsen the injury. In such cases, manual inline stabilization (MILS) or alternative techniques, like video laryngoscopy, should be used. C. Attempts to align thyroglossal and glossomental axis to improve intubating view There are no such anatomical axes as "thyroglossal" or "glossomental." These terms are not relevant to the principles of airway alignment during intubation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the clinic for pre-operative evaluation. The patient says he is feeling well, remembers many years ago, was diagnosed with some joint condition, and was advised to take mediations for which he would have to do blood tests regularly. He was not interested in doing the regular blood tests and seeing a clinician regularly, hence he never took treatment for the disease. On examination has bilateral ulnar deviation and subluxation of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints. Hand X-ray shows erosions of MCP and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-CCP antibodies are positive. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rheumatoid arthritis is a disease of the synovium. At the spine, C1 and C2 are the only vertebral bodies that have synovium. Hence, the only vertebral bodies which RA involves are C1 and C2. When RA affects the synovium tissue between these C1 (atlas) and C2 (axis), it may result in abnormal movement of the atlas relative to the axis. This abnormal movement may result in injury to the spinal cord. The involvement of the atlantoaxial joint generally occurs in patients with long-standing RA. These patients often have severe peripheral disease, joint deformities of the hands as a result of RA. Erosion might be present on radiographs. Most of the time, these patients have not been adequately managed for RA. This may be due to a lack of regular follow up for RA due to nonadherence or other reasons. When RA patients are about to undergo general anesthesia, it is best to have an X-ray of cervical spine to evaluate for atlantoaxial instability to prevent any damage to the spinal cord at the time of intubation.
