questions.text: A 67-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, and end-stage renal disease presents for open reduction and internal fixation of the right humerus fracture following a fall. His vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 145/78 mmHg, a heart rate of 85/min, respiratory rate of 16/min, and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Laboratory values are noted for hemoglobin of 10.4 g/dL, sodium of 147 mEq/L, potassium of 5.6 mEq/L, urea of 43 mg/dL, and a creatinine of 2.4 mg/dL. Serum glucose is 242 mg/dL. Using the revised cardiac risk index, what is this patient's risk of perioperative major adverse cardiovascular events?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This patient has 2 predictors for cardiac risk: insulin-dependent diabetes and chronic renal disease with a creatinine > 2 g/dL. According to the Revised Cardiac Risk Index ( RCRI) patients with a score of 2 or more have an elevated risk of developing major adverse cardiovascular events. Clinical predictors of risk of perioperative cardiovascular events include High-risk type of surgery 1 History of ischemic heart disease 1 History of congestive heart failure 1 History of cerebrovascular disease 1 Preoperative treatment with insulin 1 Preoperative serum creatinine >2.0 mg/dL 1 Risk of developing major adverse cardiovascular events is dependent on score. Final RCRI Score Risk Group 0 Low Risk 1-2 Intermediate Risk 3-6 High Risk Major adverse cardiovascular events are described as Myocardial infarction Pulmonary edema Ventricular fibrillation Primary cardiac arrest Complete heart block.

choices.text: Mallampati class IV: easy to intubate
Mallampati class I: requires surgical preparation
Mallampati class II: moderately difficult to intubate

questions.text: An unvaccinated 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with a fever, sore throat, and poor appetite for the last two days. She is accompanied by her mother, who states that her daughter has been very tired, unwilling to go to soccer practice, and claims that she has been eating less despite offering her favourite food. When asked her name, her response is muffled and barely audible. On oral exam, there is an erythematous soft palate with half of the uvula visible. What is the most appropriate characterization of this child's airway if intubation is necessary?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Unvaccinated children should always raise concern for dangerous infectious pathogens. • Muffled voices, particularly in children, is an ominous sign of potential airway compromise. • Intubation difficulty can be determined using the L.E.M.O.N. criteria: look for facial structure or injury, evaluate 3-3-2, Mallampati Class, obstruction of the airway, neck mobility. Mallampati classifications • Class 1: tonsillar pillars, uvula, soft palate and hard palate all visible • Class 2: tip of uvula obscured • Class 3: the entire uvula is occluded except for the base • Class 4: only hard palate visible

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a past medical history of major depression on selegiline, obesity, prostatic hyperplasia on tamsulosin, and hypertension on telmisartan and presents for a same-day arthritic joint augmentation surgery. His only complaints are of joint pain and increased nocturia over the past few years, and he has been catheterized multiple times in recent months due to urinary retention. Vital signs include blood pressure 148/90 mmHg, heart rate 88/min, respiratory rate of 16/min, and a temperature 37 C. Physical exam is significant for decreased range of motion in the right knee and obese abdomen. Shortly after induction, his blood pressure drops to 84/60 mmHg, and heart rate becomes 60/min. What from this patient's history makes ephedrine the most unfavourable for re-establishing a normal blood pressure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The contraindications existing for ephedrine include acute hypertension, tachycardia, and recent monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI) use within 14 days. • Instances that require caution for use include a history of coronary artery disease because of increased cardiometabolic demands, aortic stenosis because of increased heart rate, and urinary retention. • MAOIs are not recommended for use with medications like pseudoephedrine, phenylephrine, ephedrine, and phenylpropanolamine. The combination of MAO inhibitors and these drugs can cause an acute hypertensive episode.

choices.text: Keep the patient paralyzed after intubation so he cannot self-extubate himself
Plan tracheostomy as the patient has a difficult airway
Place "Difficult Airway" sign outside of the patient's room
Avoid suctioning the patient as it will traumatize the tissue and it will lead to airway oedema

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with COPD, congestive heart failure, diabetes mellitus, and hypothyroidism presents to the emergency department with cough and shortness of breath. The patient is found to have acute on chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure. His pH on arterial blood gas is 7.1, pCO2 90 mmHg, and pO2 100 mmHg on a nonrebreather mask. Upon evaluating his mouth, the clinician is unable to pass more than two fingers between upper and lower teeth. Because of the possibility of a difficult airway, the patient is intubated with a video laryngoscope after giving intravenous etomidate and rocuronium. The patient is now transferred to ICU. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • The 3-3-2 rule helps to predict difficult airway. This patient has fewer than 2 fingers width between upper and lower teeth which predicts difficult airway. • In the case of a difficult airway, the patient is usually intubated with rapid sequence intubation where paralytic medications are given. • These medications should not be given continuously once the patient is intubated. The continuous infusion of paralytic medication increases the risk of myopathy. • Once the patient with difficult airway is intubated, it is important that the interprofessional team in the ICU is aware of the patient's difficult airway. This can be achieved by placing the "Difficult Airway" sign outside of the patient's room. • "Difficult Airway" sign allows respiratory therapists to have emergency intubation kit ready in the ICU if patient's self-extubates or fails planned extubation.

choices.text: Using corticosteroids during the process of intubation
Assessing for high-risk airway before the intubation

questions.text: A 66-year-old female with a history of obstructive sleep apnoea, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, extreme obesity, and asthma presents with 5 days of worsening shortness of breath associated with wheezing and cough. Her vital signs on presentation show a blood pressure of 168/70 mmHg, oxygen saturation 85% on room air, respiratory rate 32/min, and pulse 110/min. On exam, she has diffuse expiratory wheezing. Her chest x-ray does not show any major infiltrates. Her labs are grossly normal except her ABG shows a pH of 7.2 with pCO2 56 mmHg, pO2 55 mmHg and bicarbonate of 21 mmol/L. She is started on nebulization, corticosteroids, and antibiotics. She is placed on a BiPAP and transferred to a step-down unit. Repeat ABG shows a pH of 7.1 with pCO2 of 70 mmHg. She is prepared to be intubated and moved to the ICU. Rapid sequence intubation is attempted but failed after 4 attempts. The patient goes into bradycardia and codes. Which of the following would have best prevented the patient coding?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • The patient is extremely obese and has very high-risk airway. • The clinician should have quickly triaged the patient for high-risk airway and accordingly called anesthesia. • Recognizing that patient’s airway will be difficult allows the clinician to plan for and minimize the risks of airway related morbidity. • The 3:3:2 rule plays a crucial role in planning. • It is the estimated measurement of three separate distances on the patient using the examiner's fingers. 3: Measurement of the Inter-incisor space, which should be greater than three fingers distance between the upper and lower teeth of the open mouth of a patient. 3: Measurement of the hyoid-mental distance, which should be greater than three fingers from the anterior tip of the mandible to the anterior neck on the hyoid bone 2: Measurement of the hyoid-thyroid cartilage distance, which should be greater than two fingers between the floor of the mandible at the hyoid bone to the thyroid notch on the anterior neck. • It is essential to anticipate when a difficult airway may occur. Many patients that otherwise appear normal/easy to intubate may prove difficult. The 3:3:2 rule can help to anticipate complications.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting 7 years back , hypertension, and diabetes mellitus presents complaining of a chest wall abscess. He was recently evaluated by the surgery service that recommended excision. Vital signs showed a temperature of 98.6 F, a pulse of 66 bpm, a blood pressure of 124/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination revealed a 2.5 x 3.0 x 2.0 abscess posterior to the pectoralis major. The patient has been living alone in his house and taking care of his home on his own. He did not have any history of any admission for his cardiac complaints after his last surgery 7 years back. What is the next best step in this patient's management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Intrathoracic and intraabdominal surgeries are considered high-risk surgeries. Low-risk surgeries include superficial procedures, breast surgery, cataract surgery, endoscopy, and electroconvulsive therapy. • CARDIOVASCULAR COMPLICATIONS are the major causes of perioperative morbidity and mortality, with myocardial infarctions occurring in 1% to 3% of unselected patients undergoing major noncardiac surgery • There is an increased incidence of cardiac disease and comorbidities in older patients undergoing elective non cardiac surgery • Preoperative optimization is essential to decrease the risk of postoperative Major Adverse Cardiac Events (MACE). • The ACC/AHA guidelines provide a suitable framework for evaluating cardiac risk • This is based on the presence of potentially serious cardiac disorders including CAD, congestive heart failure, valvular heart disease, and arrhythmias. • The preoperative cardiac evaluation for noncardiac surgery also emphasizes the patient’s functional status and understanding the surgical risk. • This risk assessment allows physicians to assign a clinical risk profile to an individual patient, which allows cardiologists, anaesthesiologists, and surgeons to make informed treatment decisions that may influence short-term and long-term cardiovascular outcomes Patients who have been assessed to have a high combined risk (>1%) of MACE and who have poor or unknown exercise tolerance may benefit from further testing ( PHARMACOLOGICAL STRESS TESTING) and reassessment of risk/benefit of the surgery based on test results • Patients with any of these conditions usually are referred for coronary angiography to assess the severity of CAD. • Patients presenting with acute coronary syndromes. These syndromes include: (1) Acute myocardial infarction with evidence of significant myocardial ischemia based on clinical symptoms or non-invasive cardiac testing (2) Unstable or severe angina (3) New or poorly controlled ischemic heart failure.

questions.text: A 24-week-pregnant G3P2 woman presents to the hospital for right lower quadrant abdominal pain. Detailed evaluation is highly suggestive of acute appendicitis and the patient is being prepared for surgery. What is the most appropriate least NPO time for a light meal in such patients?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • The upper esophageal sphincter is made of striated muscle and is not affected by progesterone, but anesthetic induction will reduce its tone. • Parturients are held to strict NPO guidelines (2 hours for clear liquids, 6 hours for a light meal and 8 hours for a fatty solid meal). • Chemical pneumonitis is more likely following aspiration if pH < 2.5 and volume is at least 0.3 mL/kg body weight. • Knowledge, medical expertise, and appropriate fasting intervals have made aspiration uncommon currently, with an incidence of 1 in 3216 procedures, with a much higher risk in emergency procedures.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of ischemic heart disease requires an elective surgical procedure. The patient underwent a percutaneous coronary intervention with the placement of a drug eluting stent in one of the coronaries 5 months back. The patient is completely resolved of his symptoms after the PCI and is on dual antiplatelet therapy since then. Which of the following is a valid reason for delaying surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Dual antiplatelet therapy continuation • After a coronary stent placement, dual anti platelet therapy (aspirin + clopidogrel) is started to prevent restenosis and stent thrombosis. • Use of dual anti platelet agents also poses a risk of bleeding during the surgery. • There has to be a minimum time interval before which DAPT shouldn’t be stopped. • This depends on the type of PCI done. During this period elective non cardiac surgery has to be delayed. • Balloon angioplasty: 14 days • Bare metal stent: 30 days • Drug eluting stent: 365 days • Elective non cardiac surgery can be considered after 180 days if the risk of delaying a surgery is more than the risk of stent thrombosis

choices.text: Succinylcholine may cause further liver damage
The use of succinylcholine may cause excessive potassium release
The patient may have decreased levels of pseudocholinesterase enzyme

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with type 2 diabetes, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, dementia, and severe liver dysfunction from long term non-alcoholic fatty liver disease presents to the hospital with upper gastrointestinal bleeding. She is planned for endoscopy under anesthesia due to her comorbidities and history of prolonged mechanical ventilation after elective surgery. Family history is notable for a younger brother with a similar history of prolonged mechanical ventilation after surgery. Her current medications include metformin, glyburide, nadolol, omeprazole, tacrine, and lactulose. Which of the following should be taken into consideration before succinylcholine can is used?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Pseudocholinesterase is produced in the liver, and severe liver disease may result in significant pseudocholinesterase deficiency due to decreased production. • The patient is also taking tacrine hydrochloride, which is an anticholinesterase that interferes with pseudocholinesterase activity, thus adding to the already decreased ability to degrade succinylcholine. • The patient’s personal and family histories are suggestive of a possible inherited pseudocholinesterase deficiency as well. • Acquired pseudocholinesterase deficiencies may occur with severe liver disease, myxoedema, acute or chronic infections, cardiac disease, and chronic renal failure. • Malnutrition and pregnancy may also result in an acquired form of the disease. • Medications that inhibit pseudocholinesterase or directly decrease its rate of production include organophosphates, corticosteroids, cytotoxic drugs, and cholinesterase inhibitors. • A combination of subclinical inherited pseudocholinesterase deficiency and subclinical acquired pseudocholinesterase deficiency can result in a clinically significant overall deficiency of the enzyme with a significant risk of prolonged action of succinylcholine and mivacurium. • In this patient, there is a possibility of an inherited deficiency as well as two forms of acquired deficiency of the enzyme.

questions.text: Best marker to know whether ET tube is in correct position is: -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Oxygen saturation is not a reliable marker for correct position. Option B-Position of ET tube Can either be in the esophagus or trachea. To confirm the placement of tube,End tidal CO2 is measured. Option C-Auscultation of chest can be done,but End tidal CO2 is a better marker. Option D-ECG is used to look at functioning of heart,not lungs.

questions.text: Identify the capnogram?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Intraoperative bronchospasm will result in shark fin appearance. Option B-Spontaneous breathing under the effect of muscle relaxation results in curare notch as shown in image. Option C-Rebreathing of CO2 will result in inspiratory curve not touching baseline. Option D-Hypoventilation will result in increase concentration of ETCO2 on capnography.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A-BMI>30 i.e, obese are at risk of Pulmonary complications. Option B-Upper abdominal surgery causes a splinting effect on breathing resulting in basal atelectasis of lungs. Option C-Patient with 40 pack years of smoking are at risk of Pulmonary complications. questions.text: arrange in sequence the following steps of intubation : A. Head extension and neck flexion B. Introduction of laryngoscope C. Inflation of cuff D. Check breath sounds with stethoscope
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Steps of intubation are:- A. Head extension and neck flexion. B. Introduction of laryngoscope and then introduce ETT. C. Inflation of cuff Of ETT with air. D. Check breath sounds with stethoscope.

questions.text: Purpose of giving glycopyrrolate before GA is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-Glycopyrrolate is not used to increase heart rate to acceptable level. Option B-To decrease the risk of aspiration,we use drugs like PPIs,which decreases gastric acid production. Option C-Glycopyrrolate is not used to maintain blood pressure. Option D-Glycopyrrolate is an Anti cholinergic drug.It is a Premedication i.e, all the drugs that are given to the patient before induction.It decreases respiratory secretions due to its Anti cholinergic action.

questions.text: Identify the reading:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Capnography is a measure of End Tidal CO2 [ETCO2] concentration in mm Hg along with its graphical representation. Capnography is one of the essential monitors during anesthesia especially general anesthesia and is an indicator of both respiration and circulation during anesthesia.

questions.text: ASA 1 patient posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During surgery, sudden drop in ETCO2 to 8 mm hg with hypotension and tachycardia but airway pressures were 18 cm H20. What’s the diagnosis? 1) CO2 embolism 2) Pneumothorax 3) bronchospasm 4) single bronchus intubation
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1.For laparoscopy, you need to create a pneumoperitoneum,for which the gas used is CO2. SUDDEN DROP OF ETCO2 WITH HYPOTENSION AND TACHYCARDIA WITH NORMAL AIRWAY PRESSURE : CO2 embolism 2.Pneumothorax- will not cause drop in ETCO2 but it'll cause very high airway pressure as one lung is collapsed by pneumothorax. 3.Bronchospasm- airway pressure will not be normal,it will be increased 4.Single bronchus intubation: fall in ETCO2 will not be there.

questions.text: A 15 year old boy reported to emergency with breathing difficulty. Monitor was attached and the following graph was seen on capnography.The diagnosis can be:- 1. Pericarditis 2. Acute bronchial asthma 3. Cardiac tamponade 4. Bronchospasm
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The given capnogram shows a sharkfin pattern, which is typical of Asthma or COPD or bronchospasm. This shape is due to the abnormal plateau phase, representing limited expiration which may be caused by increased airway resistance and possible bronchospasm or other obstruction of exhalation.

questions.text: In a patient with thrombocytopenia, in order to proceed with surgery platelet transfusion is done to achieve a platelet level of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The minimum platelet count to proceed with surgery is 50,000.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis in a patient undergoing cardiac surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A,B,C-Penicillin,Erythromycin and Azithromycin are not used. Option D-First and second generation cephalosporins(cefazolin) are the drugs of choice for preoperative prophylaxis for cardiac surgery. Preoperative antibiotic prophylaxis is essential in reducing the risk of surgical site infections.

questions.text: Identify a 2nd generation supraglottic airway device?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) There are broadly two types of Supraglottic airway device:- first generation (classic LMA, Unique, AuraOnce, AuraStraight). second generation (e.g. i-Gel, LMA Pro-Seal, LMA-Supreme, AuraGain). The main difference between the two being is that the second generation has a gastric lumen that allows for drainage of gastric fluids or secretions.

choices.text: Severe illness which is life threatening.

questions.text: Correct about ASA-3 class is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) ASA classification is as follows:- 1-A person in good health. 2-A mild but well-managed or treated condition. 3-A serious condition that has an impact on a person’s overall health. 4-A severe condition that’s life-threatening. 5-A life-threatening condition that needs immediate surgery to increase survival odds. 6-A deceased person who is an organ donor.

questions.text: AMBU AURA 40 IS?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 2ND GENERATION LMA The AMBU Aura 40 is classified as a second-generation laryngeal mask airway (LMA). Unlike first-generation LMAs, which lack advanced features like gastric access or reinforced tubing, second-generation LMAs such as the Aura 40 incorporate improvements like a preformed curved stem for easier insertion, a softer cuff for better sealing, and enhanced safety features to reduce the risk of airway obstruction. However, it does not have a dedicated gastric drainage channel, which is a hallmark of third-generation LMAs (e.g., LMA ProSeal or LMA Supreme). The AMBU Aura series is designed for single use and is widely utilized in anesthesia for its reliability and ease of placement, making it a standard second-generation LMA option in clinical practice.
